reviews.review_text: Game servers are broken for long time. Every minute game tries to connect to those broken server and causes major freeze. Achievement system doesn't work too. Support ignores all request and doesn't want to speak.

No no no no.  It's a promising TD game. Good graphic, decent mechanics (using card system to deploy tower and it has even magic and talent trees) but the game is not even supported. You'll see your screen freezes every random seconds. Some can mitigate the effect by blocking the game's exe in Windows firewall to stop sending handshakes to external servers.   And the servers... are dead. Leaderboards? Bye bye.  More so, not only have the developers terminated the support without warning, leaving paying players on Steam to see the free counterpart on other websites updated continously is just daylight insult.  Fool me once, shame on me. Fool me twice, shame on this horrible business practice (they had the guts to promote their mobile games on this game's Store Page when abandoning the game).  You'd be better off playing TD like Sanctum or the legendary Defense Grid series.

Lets start of by saying that i havent played a lot of tower defence games but if a fair few have the quality that this game does then i think i will be playing a fair few others. When i started playing the game i was like 'I really like the setting' (huge fantasy fan me) 'but do i really like the style of gameplay that this sort of game has'. Then i watched as time went by and i realised this is exactally the sort of game i love to spend time with,the setting is pure fantasy and is well represented in game with the graphics,sound and script. The game plays out from battle to battle and you gain coin and different cards that you can use in battles defending the entrance that the demons (from bouncing heads on sticks to exploding frogs-GO FIGURE) try to reach and if they do so in a certain number then its 'GAME OVER MAN' (couldent resisit the quote there). The cards are also used in between levels in upgrading the towers you have,and beleive me when i tell you that this plays a heavy part in the game as dont upgrade and you are not going to proceed any further than where you are at that certain point in the game.Grinding plays quite a huge role in the game and is an important part of being able to upgrade the equipment you have so you can get that one level closer to the finishing line and the demon who seems to want your head on a pole. Like i have allready said i really liked the game and after playing for a while (havent quite finished just yet-but dont think it will change my opinion on the game as i will still regard it as a game i would reccommend to anyone with a love of tower defence games) then decided to buy another tower defence game (well the pack) ANOMOLY 2 and found that i really like that game also. So sometimes it is good to play games you arent used to as you then find that sometimes a change can be just what you needed and that a game style you have never played before can get you gaming in ways you never thought you would.
While I really like this game and it has a lot of potential, the mere fact that the Steam version does not get updated while the free to play versions do is enough for me to not recommend this.

It's too bad the devs just let this game rot. I don't really understand how they can still sell something that only half works. It's a decent tower defense game, but since they apparently don't support it anymore, I won't be recommending this.

While an excellent tower defence game, which includes RPG and card collecting elements, it unfortunately contains far too much grinding, and doesn't progress quickly enough. So why am I recommending it? Well, because for what you get out of it, Prime World: Defenders is certainly worth playing. :3

This game really feels like a free to play game stripped of all it's microtransactions. You might think that sounds like a good thing but what is left is a confused and horribly unbalanced game.  I spent my first 8 or 9 hours breezing through the game at a steady pace before hitting a brick wall of challenge which is insurmountable without resorting to endless grinding. Your towers come in the form of cards. You need to collect several of the same cards to upgrade them and progress however the only way of obtaining cards is by finding them at random or by purchasing them with in-game credits. You can't choose which ones you buy with your credits though, that is also left to chance. You'll soon run out of credits though and In a freemium game you would be able to purchase in-game credits to top up if you wanted, in this game however, the only way to earn credits is by grinding. Grinding can often be fun in a game, here it is so ineffective that it feels like an utterly pointless endeavour. You grind away hoping to be rewarded with the cards you need to upgrade and progress yet all the end of level rewards feel about 3 levels behind where you need them to be, meaning the cards you want, the cards you NEED, rarely come up. By the time you've fully upgraded a few towers the game ramps up the difficulty and they are rendered ineffective. You need to upgrade the new towers. Your magic abilities are absolutely useless, the fuse and evolution function is over complicated and there are frankly just too many towers with too many different enemies with the same levels rehashed over and over. It's a mess to be honest and the in-game currency, leveling up system along with the grinding nature of the gameplay and 'daily rewards' and 'special offer's' on items all scream freemium. Yet this isn't a freemium game, so it's all a bit redundant.   All in all then Prime World Defenders' as a game is basically thus: Want to obtain more towers? Grind. Want to unlock new abilities? Grind. Want to upgrade your towers so you can beat the level and progress? GRIND. Just don't expect grinding to get you anywhere.

The game leaves a bitter-sweet taste of unpolished product with a potential to be great but also lack of attention to details and way to slow of a progress. The game simply does not feel rewarding.  Pros: - cards mechanics - in the sea of many FPS/TD hybrids, this one falls quite close to a regular TD game  Cons: - no enemies in current wave amount indicator - hard to select towers - unresponsive keyboard shortcuts (sometimes they work, sometimes you need to press them twice) - slow progress - repetitive maps - too much grind  Perhaps try it..

I want to recommend this game, I really do. It has nice graphics, the sound effects and music is nice, the voice work is pretty good. No bugs that I've seen and nothing that really irks me.  However, I can't recommend it. The game has been left for dead by the developers in favor of the Free to Play version on Kongregate. This version has been left to rot with no updates unlike its free variant. So if this game looks amazing and you really and you think it's worth the money, then don't buy it, go play it for free and save the money.
Get Defense Grid or Pixel Junk Monsters instead. The demo pretty much IS the game. There's nothing else beyond it.

The most important thing about a game is 'is it fun?' All of the warts don't really matter if you're smiling a bit as you play.   Prime World: Defenders is fun, especially if you like tower defense games (TD). The UI is near enough to perfect that it should be standard to TD games the same way that WASD is standard to FPS games. Yup, its that good! The gameplay mechanics are pretty standard, the baddies come marching in, dumb and happy to a horrible end, killed by bog standard towers. Oh well, you don't fix what ain't broke!  The innovation appears in the form of a random collectable card mechanic where you get random cards as loot for beating a map, which are towers, artifacts, or magic. You can combine two of the same to evolve it, allowing towers to be upgraded or you can fuse multiple cards into one to increase its level, making it more powerful. Its more complicated than I'm explaining it, and its very satisfying. My only beef is with the voice acting, which is awful, but skippable.  Now go away, I'm gonna play some more!

A well executed twist of a tower defense mixed with card collection. Involves strategy, but allow different strategies to beat the levels, which is always nice. I hate games where you are given a bunch of options, but to win you have to chose a particular one. Never felt this was one of those games.   You eventually will have to grind, but i found it an enjoyable grinding never felt repetitive. Mainly because, while 'grinding' you can beat one mission you already passed trying new cards/spells you earned. It's like you are grinding but at the same time, you are training and experimenting the best ways to beat the upcoming levels. You get the feel that you are always progressing, which i appreciate a lot.  The card evolution/fusing system it's also very interesting, and adds a lot to the game. The visuals and voice acting are also enjoyable, not great, but they do their job decently.

I feel the metacritic rating for this game is pointlessly harsh.  I quite enjoyed myt ime with Prime World: Defenders! The art style is pretty enjoyable, the towers are fun, and I really liked the CCG mechanics. There IS grinding in this game, but I was never really afraid to grind. Only once (to get a full dragon tower) did it feel like a slog.  Anyways, it's a fun tower defense game. The story is... well, not great. The voice acting could use some work, but at least the art direction is pretty good. There was a relatively decent selection of maps, and each time it's slightly randomized to add a bit of replayability.  Anyways, I had fun with it and if combining CCG and Tower Defense mechanics is alluring to you, I think you'll like it too!

Love this game, its a great single player defense game, it uses the basic defense game features, you position your defenses in specific locations to stop the waves of enemies reaching there target, you then collect resources by killing enemies, the more you collect the more defenses you can use against the enemy as the waves get bigger and stronger.  You play alot of the same maps but they do change as you progress through the game. They also use a card feature where you use and collect specific cards for better defenses and upgrades etc, its good fun.
A bit grind-ish, but lots of fun. Wish it would get the updates that the free version has.   Devs, if you see this, please give us an update, we already gave you (some) of our money! :)
Excellent Card Game - Tower Defense Hybrid. A little bit grindy but fun anyway.
Good TD with collectible cards mechanic, but very grindy.

This is fun!  PD is my first Tower Defense game. I like the card aspect of the game, as wellas talents. Graphics are pretty cool, the monsters look good. I think these are the best kobolds I have ever seen. I did read that there is some grinding involved, but I've had fun replaying the first few maps just to get three stars and the achievements, so no problem for me.

A great game, sadly the developers have abandoned it while they work on their mobile port.  At the time of writing, the Steam release is at version 1.1 (or 1.2, depending on where you look..) while the mobile port is @ version 1.7.

A mediocre tower defense game. There are much better on the market.

A surprisingly decent tower defence game.   Although the sound and graphics scream mobile port, unlike some, it has been balanced well so that it doesn't feel like you are grinding pointlessly in the absence of microtransactions (looking at you, Antisquad).  The diverse maps, enemies and towers ensure plenty of variety, and the card-based tower collection and crafting makes even a quick match feel worthwhile.
A really good tower defense game. It's also on mobile for free.

a great TD game. Colorful, fun towers, and a interesting card based upgrade path that would have been easy to add microtransactions to, but thankfully they have not. Bonus points for not being a crappy company.
Nice game!! Really fun!! Recommended +1 ^_^
Not so bad, if you like TD games and don't mind replaying a lot. It helps that the graphics are good and the turret unlocking/progressing is compeling. It gets better.

My first impressions of Prime World: Defendersâ¦  I like it A LOT!!! Yes, there is a lot of grinding to do and I am not that far into it, so I am not going to really review the game yet. Just know that I play a lot of Tower Defense (TD ) games and so far Prime World: Defenders is one of my favorite. The 3D graphics are superb, the gameplay is fun, but might be a bit grindy for some people, the sound is great with excellent music. Every thing else is done right and very colorful! All the menus are pleasing to the eye and the world map is awesome! The choice of creatures is the best feature and they are all rendered in stunning 3D!!! The towers and animations look great! The list goes on and on...  The only negative thing that I found was that you can only grind the maps so many times before you stop getting silver and experience points for beating them. Then you have to move along to the next map and grind that map to it's max times. I think you can grind each map around 10 times or so. I haven't counted, but it's enough to get some of your perks leveled up. The cards really only represent the towers and do not come into play during combat like the card game Magic. You will stack them to level your towers and magic, so to speak. There are special cards to find and add to your towers too. This is all done outside of combat. Combat is your typical tower defense setup, but leveling towers happens outside of combat. Makes sense and is pretty cool! :-)  The game is a little hard, but easier than some of the other TD games I've played. I'll have to play some more and then come back and review it. I do like it a lot so far. The game is solid and has not crashed on me yet.  Here are my system specifications: iMac, i5 Quad-Core Intel processor 3.1GHZ, AMD Radeon HD 6970M with 1GB dedicated video RAM, 4GB system RAM, 1TB hard drive running OS X version 10.6.8.
brilliant tower defence game, very fun and well made
addictive and easy to learn. stayed up till 4 am too many times playing this game. still like it. not a 'pay to win' game.

This is a great tower defense game if you are into that style. It is mixed a bit with card booster mechanics (100% free all in game money not real money) This really adds a bit of randomness and allows some replayability through the game. It can however cause a bit of grinding and a little bit of bad luck but still a great game.
One of the more fun TD game. But requires a lot of grinding.
A really good combination of TD and card collecting. I certainly recommend it if you are a fan of either or both genres!
Fun game, but would be better if it was multiplayer :(
Really good Tower Defense game!
I really don't understand the low metacritic reviews. I think this is easily one of the best TD games I've ever played. If you like TD and like getting random drops, this is for you.

since i cannot unlock this games achievements with sam (steam achievement manager) i decided 2 play this game.  soooo. this game doesnt suck. thats good, played it 11 hours, still doesnt suck, thats even more good!

Pretty fun tower defense game, cool card/upgrade system that adds a lot of replayability and collecting. Can get a little grindy, as you will get a 'skill check' every once in a while that basically means you don't have enough perks/upgrades to move forward in the game. Addictive, fun & challenging

If you enjoy tower defenses this is probably a good game for you to pick up. It features character advancement (that is, experience gain and levels), two forms of long term resources to spend (silver and stars) which also help you increase your strength, and tower growth through evolution and fusion.  The graphics are well done; I generally don't play with sound on so I couldn't tell you much about the sound effects or music. It's currently in beta but seems extremely polished for that state.  The only complain I have is that grinding for silver can be tedious at times, but I'm ignoring the very first piece of advice the game gave me, 'Don't try for perfect on your first try; you can come back for it when you're stronger.' I can't really hold my personal failings against the game. :)

Pretty and fun, easy going tower defense game with fanciful graphics and animations. Story is a tacked-on fail, though the illustrations are pleasant. Recommended and wish I could pay for an expansion. Wish tower forging were more interesting (more like hybridization weirdness instead of simply going up levels of power).  great job, devs

Prime World: Defenders gets it right by combining a solid understanding of tower defense concepts with a card game. You're not just strategizing tower placement but building and maintaining a 'deck' of towers and spells. The fusing system allows you to combine and upgrade the cards you win through victories or purchase at the store (using in-game currency.) This game is a fair deal at $10 and a steal at $3.40!

[I'm probably about 25 hours into this game as I sit down to write my review. I've played the game enitirely in off-line mode, so I can't speak to any Steam-related issues or capacities.]  I'm a big-fan of the tower-defense genre, and have been playing them from way back in the Warcraft 3 modding-days, when there were dozens available, and many had very innovative concepts. Prime World: Defenders does a great job at incorporating many different Tower Defence elements into one game, in a way that is mostly smooth and satisfying.   I'll highlight those positive tower-defence elements in this review: -Levels are loseable, due to failed strategy, random difficulty changes, or not having leveled up enough. This makes winning more rewarding, and the game more depthful. -Many towers are availble in the game, and you get to select up to 7 of them for each battle, making your strategy personal and adaptable. -You can use spells in addition to towers to add an extra layer of strategy and the need for awareness. -You can 'rush' the next wave of enemies for a bonus of money to build your towers. This adds both more strategy, and an ability to get in over your head. -There is a leveling up system for your towers and spells, which adds elements of both luck and personalization to your resources. -There are a modest variety of monsters, and while I wouldn't mind more, each type has strengths and weaknesses and the balance works well for the game. -Ability to replay levels, either for resource farming, or to improve scores/records and secondary objectives. -Each time you play a level, the map is generated to have differences in the tiles. A tile could be open, boosted, or blocked. This significantly changes the strategy and difficulty of the level. The type of monsters, and the order of waves also changes/  Also positive: I find the graphics to be both attractive, and more importantly, clear- I can tell what is going on with the battle at a glance. There is a story, which while not particularly incredible so far, takes place in an imaginative world.   The negatives are as follows: -Sometimes you end up having to grind in order to buildup the resources you need to develop your towers and be able to move forward. -Maps are reused frequently in the beginning, and while there are changes to both the map tiles and monsters, it grows tiring to keep replaying he same maps if you choose to grind early on. -Sometimes the display radius of a tower does not display properly, or does not seem to match up with the tower's ability to hit monsters. -The tower and spell-leveling systems are very simple, but poorly explained. I was very confused in the beginning, and there are still some nuances regarding cost that I have not worked out. -The 'percent efficiency boost' that notifies you what leveling up a tower or spell does is sometimes innaccurate.  Overall I feel this game is a solid investment for fans of the genre. I think it is depthful and strategic, and brings in a lot of nuance and a fair amount of challenge. The downside is that you may spend significant time grinding instead of moving forward, so the game might be a poor choice for people who want to play and beat a game, quick and simple.
Nice tower defence with a twist :)

A must-have for any tower defence fan! I purchased because of my love for the genre and the neat card-collection mechanic. After logging in 10+ hours, I'm only half of the way through the game! The randomized levels is a great feature, too. Certain aspects of the level are changed every mission (for side-missions), which keeps gameplay fresh while you adapt to each new scenario! My girlfriend watched me play for three hours straight the night I bought it. The next day I picked it up for her too because she had so much fun just watching/helping me play. Couldn't be happier with this game!
Tower Defense + EXP System + Talent Tree + Collectible Card Game = Addicting!

Very interesting CCG TD combo which is good fun to play and offers a fair amount of strategy and variation BUT there is a lot of grinding involved - a LOT. You cannot complete the game without grinding for at least 5 - 10 hours because you won't have the good towers yet and/or your towers will simply be too weak.  If you don't like spending hours grinding away then I would recommend you play as far as you can until you hit a grind point then take a break and come back every now and then. This way it doesn't feel like a chore and you can keep your entertainment levels up. I took two weeks to finish this and I enjoyed my time doing so. If you do enjoy grinding then you'll love this game.  TIP: As soon as you see any purple catds, grab them. They are far better than the other cards, especially once evolved and fused to max.
a pretty solid and addictive TD. it even allow mazing on some levels.
